qas.question: What are thick alloys made in layers called?
What does Liquidmetal Technologies use for their alloys?
What type of metal makes better alloys than traditional steel?
At what university was Klement a student?
What are thick alloys made in crystals called?
What does Liquidmetal Technologies use for their cooling?
What type of metal makes better alloys than Caltech?
At what university did Klement produce BMGs?

context: In the past, small batches of amorphous metals with high surface area configurations (ribbons, wires, films, etc.) have been produced through the implementation of extremely rapid rates of cooling. This was initially termed "splat cooling" by doctoral student <a0_0><b5_0>W. Klement<b5_0/><a0_0/> at <a4_0><b9_0>Caltech<b9_0/><a4_0/>, who showed that cooling rates on the order of millions of degrees per second is sufficient to impede the formation of crystals, and the metallic atoms become "locked into" a glassy state. Amorphous metal wires have been produced by sputtering molten metal onto a spinning metal disk. More recently a number of alloys have been produced in layers with thickness exceeding 1 millimeter. These are known as <a1_0><b6_0>bulk metallic glasses<b6_0/><a1_0/> (BMG). Liquidmetal Technologies sell a number of <a2_0><b7_0>zirconium<b7_0/><a2_0/>-based BMGs. Batches of <a3_0><b8_0>amorphous steel<b8_0/><a3_0/> have also been produced that demonstrate mechanical properties far exceeding those found in conventional steel alloys.
